This first phase will only concern the state of Abidjan and aims to vaccinate 2 groups. The first group is made up of health personnel, defense and security forces as well as teachers. description: The Ivory Coast is enforcing a travel ban for all non- citizens entering from a country that has more than a hundred confirmed COVID- 19 cases. description:
the reopening of hajj pilgrim travels from Ivory Coast with certain conditions needed for the hajj candidate to be able to do the pilgrimage, which is:

1. It needs to be a person from age 18-60
2. a candidate needs to be vaccinated and receive a certificate of vaccination from the government
3. a candidate must not carry/have a history of vulnerable diseases
4. Done pre-pilgrimage medical consultations
5. Have his/her name listed and officially identified by the Hajj pilgrimage commissariat
6. As part of the Saudi Arabian guideline, the candidate needs to be tested negative with a PCR one week before the departure and must be wearing masks at all times during the pilgrimage
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry),People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry),People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19,Other population not specifed above

description: The Ivory Coast will pay all electricity bills of those families considered vulnerable and subscribed to the "social tariff of electricity"(tarif social d’électricité). This concerns all electricity bills that are to be on April and May 2020 UPDATE: The original economic support was set to April or March, it has been extended to April and May
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Government Announced a plan to relaunch the economy after Covid-19. This plan is called the Economic, Social, and Humanitarian Support Plan aimed at maintaining economic activity, preserving employment, and promoting a rapid recovery after the health crisis. This plan consists of CFAF 1,700 billion. Said plan is structured around four (4) Funds. Namely, the Large Business Support Fund, with a target allocation of CFAF 100 billion; the SME Support Fund, endowed with CFAF 150 billion; the Support Fund for Informal Sector Actors, endowed with CFAF 100 billion; and the Humanitarian Emergency Solidarity and Support Fund, with a target allocation of CFAF 170 billion
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: It is an economic plan aimed to relaunch the economy after the Covid-19 pandemic outbreak
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: WHO is reinforcing the remote training scheme of INSP and 85 health districts in Ivory Coast. Donations include laptops and desktops, cabinets, inverters, stabilizers, fly box internet, cameras with tripods and microphones, mixing tables, TV sets, sound bars, internet servers and all accessories, this initial investment is estimated at FCFA 300 million. This has been announced on June 5th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Support for materials, multimedia and audiovisual equipment to strengthen the training platform hosted by the Ivorian National Institute of Public Health
target_geog_level: An international organization (e.g. World Health Organization)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
Ivory Coast will be receiving a 2.2 billion CFA francs from Japan to enable it to carry out an effective fight against Covid-19.
Japanese aid will be used to strengthen the medical capacity of five hospitals in Greater Abidjan. These are the university hospitals of Cocody, Yopougon, Angré and Treichville, as well as the general hospital of Anyama. This after July 6th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: economical support from the Japanese government to the Ivorian government
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: Since March 14, Monaco decided that all private beaches have to close their door to the public. Effective May 4 and until further notice, access to natural or artificial beaches is still prohibited. Any breach is now punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. UPDATE: The policy ends on May 14. Access to beaches is now autorized under conditions.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
